bibl.title: Crooked ribs, Modern martyrs and Dull Days: Recovering Hidden Prince Edward Island Women Through Their Life Writing

div.p: Over the last century, folk songs and stories, obituaries, paintings, newspaper advertisements, and local histories have depicted Island women as mystical mermaids, biblically incited victims of their body, and sometimes as gracious and gentle women. But in their own words in their journals women write themselves through their daily rituals of managing households, planting their gardens or stretching the parameters of home; they contextualize themselves within what Kathryn Carter refers to as 'the small details' of their everyday and through deflated expressions like "dull day."

In this paper I intend to examine the images of women popularly available and juxtapose those images with the representations women generate in their life writing. Journals, diaries, and letters by women from the nineteenth and early twentieth century are not widely available; my research on twenty such Island women is based on their unpublished manuscripts obtained from the Public Archives and Records Office of Prince Edward Island (PAROPEI). Redeeming women from their place of obscurity in their diaries and locating their inscribed sites of representation have indeed opened up a new chapter in women's writing. Inspired by Sheila Rowbotham's work on women "hidden from history," I began to expand my collection of Island women's unpublished life writing and develop strategies for reading and understanding these "messy" documents.Weiland 204 Multiple readings of these diaries, ledgers, account books, and scraps of paper convinced me that the women's choice of the autobiographical genre was instrumental in their textual articulation of voice. The diary could accept entries at any time, on any subject and allow for textual resolutions unheard of elsewhere. Initially for the reader/researcher of these original handwritten texts the task of understanding the sporadic and varied handwriting and idiosyncratic textual resolutions of each diarist such as gaps, vagueness or silence about the "unsayable" seemed insurmountable. But as Rebecca Hogan has indicated, such practices are typical of l'ecriture feminine where the parataxical fragments of ungrammatical passages reflect the "non-hierarchical flow of events" that make up a woman's life.Hogan 4 The sought-after cohesion in life writing texts comes through multiple readings of the diaries and lining up these documents with other cultural artifacts such as histories, paintings or even anecdotal evidence.

Typically these ordinary women in their diaries refrained from confronting and confessing immediate threats and instead the diarist creates a lacunae or silence on the subject which the diary reader often in retrospect fills in. In the case of the five-year diary of my grandmother Amy Andrew (1881-1966), anecdotal evidence on an incident recorded and often spoken about indicated that she downplayed the accident and wrote of a "fright" (1912) while the scar on her arm spoke of a more serious accident. On other occasions she created gaps in her diary, unable to find the language for the "unsayable" situation of being newly married. Emma Chadwick Stretch (1819-1881) very discreetly disclosed her own illness in her 1859 diary, focusing primarily on her child's near-death experience. Once the child recovered, we learn from Emma's "account book" that she too had been violently ill and had lost her hearing as a result of it.

label.title: Island women diarists' representation in writing, art, and song

div.p: Numerous women diarists diverted their diary entries away from personal dilemmas and instead concentrated on the birth and death of farm animals rather than the same fates of their nearest and dearest. Lucy Palmer Haslam (1865-1943) and Amy Andrew reported on headaches at times when their words did not suffice for the anguish of the moment. Reading Lucy Palmer's 1887 entries on her early teaching experiences alongside Island artist Robert Harris's painting "The Meeting of the School Trustees" (1885) provides both a textual and visual representation of women's early entry to the public sphere. Lucy's textual trepidation matches that of the young teacher in Harris' famous painting. Amy Andrew's obvious anxiety of losing her sister Marion to the stream of outward migration was folded into the account of her withdrawal from attending church; similarly, when the mare died, she wrote again: "did not go to church." She could not admit to her sorrow but by her actions she could acknowledge an inability to fall into the social expectation of going to church, thereby indicating her sadness.

Island women's diaries have emerged like sandstones surfacing with the outgoing tide. With each receding wave more sandstones appear as the tides simultaneously expose and shape the fragile surfaces of the artifacts. Through time and systematically sifting in archives these diary gems emerged. The reading of Amy, Lucy, Emma and other Island diarists has been a task of examining the crumbling sandstone-like layers of texts and placing the diaries in a twenty-first-century setting with other nineteenth and early-twentieth-century artifacts. Newspaper archives, anthologies of folk songs and stories prove to be a rich site for finding women's visual representations in advertisements and lyrical representations in popular folk songs. Folk stories, like popular histories which currently flourish in PEI, remain faithful to a presentation of early Island women within what Bumsted refers to as the sentimentalized "specialness" of the Island.Bumsted 11

Musical lyrics of nine songs in Folksongs from Prince Edward Island, featuring women as the main thematic element and originating from the nineteenth and twentieth century, are a revealing point of departure for taking up women's imaging in popular culture, past and present. Three of the nine women in these folksongs die in circumstances of love near the sea. Consider Alice from the popular Island folksong "The Gay Spanish Maid" who dies on the shore like a rose nipped by the frost while waiting for her "gay gallant youth." Their love blossomed on the shore, where she dies of hypothermia while he returns from his wrecked ship on a plank. A familiar pattern emerges as the woman succumbs to a beautiful death and the man survives a heroic encounter with the elements. Pretty Mary in "The Murder of Mary Tuplin" was taken in by the tide and found by her parents after being murdered by her jealous lover. The bonnie lassie "Sally Munroe" was stolen away from her Belfast home by Jimmy Dixon. The sweet and pleasant gale takes Sally and Jimmy from the sandy shore in the hope of a new beginning across the sea, but the dark clouds consume their ship and the young lovers.

The six surviving women take leave of their familiar domestic sphere, their fate being linked with the dangers of moving alone in the world. The nameless woman at the Boston harbor depicted in "Coatman's Saloon" deceives her male companion by pretending to be a rich widow. The deceitful woman "Eve" in "The Crooked Rib" is wild and stubborn like an unruly horse. The flirtatious "Rose of Cumberland" with her cunning eyes fails to seduce the sportsman who insists the coastal girls are more handsome. Mary Ann of "The Jim Ross Song" dares to say "no" while there are other "maidens who cried and mourned for the groom." The snotty nosed wife in "What do you think of my darling?" inspires the husband's hope that the devil would sweep her away soon. All give a gloomy picture of the Island woman, in love and despair, particularly when she takes leave of her home for the city or the wilds of nature, and exercises her independence.

The natural landscapes of the shore, the outer limits of society figure strongly as a place of resolution for women once they have left the security of home, whether in Ireland, or Prince Edward Island itself. In retrospect, songs like "Coatman's Saloon" serve as a warning to the many young Maritime women who joined the exodus to seek employment outside the region and more specifically those who in the early 1900s headed for the Eastern States or Western Canada. Whether woman's fate be death or moral stagnation, as is the case of the "wealthy widow" of "Coatman's Saloon," departure from home was for many of the women of folksongs a fatal move. In "The Old Oak Tree" Liza fails to return home from her stormy night sojourn with Squire James MacCallum only to be found with her heart pierced by MacCallum's knife, buried under the same tree where he had once professed his love to her. Those women who challenged the proposals of men, as Mary Ann did, or initiated romance as Rose, were regarded as a threat to the status quo and were destined to be the subject of folksongs.

Historical vignettes of women written up in stories about the good old days, as Island historian David Weale has in Them Times, do not give a direct voice to women either. Such folk stories are a third-person narrative in an ethnographic form meant to depict what life was like on Prince Edward Island when the twentieth century "seemed to hit the Island." Judging by his selection of stories, women from these times are to be celebrated for their roles as mother and wife in the bosom of domesticity: "a woman's house was her person you see, and her pride and joy."Weale 21 Weale was obviously engaging in what Shirley Neuman refers to as "contemporary narratives of disappearing ways of life" as he turns his narrative into a romancing of past hardships.Neuman 349 Women, Island historian Edward MacDonald reminds us, were at this time "silent partners in the life of the Island . . . far away from the levers of social, political or economic power."MacDonald 62

p.ref: Similarly, advertisements in the Island media from the early twentieth century gave one-sided representations of women, reinforcing the myth of women as the weaker sex or even unfit for the public sphere because of their "female functions." A woman imaged in the "Modern Martyrs" advertisement, dressed in a voluptuous manner and textually portrayed as part of the age of martyrs that has not passed, stands at the stake fueled by the flames of disease, a victim of her own biology and a vehicle through which medical remedies were promoted. As Rosalind Coward writes, "women were put to work by the images" and offered man-made cures like Dr. Hugo’s Health Tablets to get relief from their "female function" and resume being healthy, happy, fertile mothers.

div.p: The obituary tends to overwrite any representation a woman may have carved out for herself during her lifetime in her journal. According to G. Thomas Couser, it is the most widely disseminated life writing genre and thus the most widely consumed by the public. When Lucy Palmer Haslam (1884-1943) died leaving twenty extensive handwritten diaries documenting her life from the age of eighteen to her time as a teacher, her marriage, and life as an entrepreneurial farm wife, her obituary spoke of her family relations and the funeral details, summing her up thus: "The late Mrs. Haslam was widely known and highly esteemed in the community in which she had lived for many years." Her volumes of texts where she discreetly reveals her apprehensions as a young teacher, her budding professionalism in the public domain, the transactions of her poultry business, are all forgotten. Lucy's obituary memorializes her within the typical frames of death writing, of chronicling and commemorating, thus ignoring the journal inscriptions of this gregarious writing subject, the one buried within the pages of her diary in the archives.

label.title: Turning to life writing and seeing women in their own words

div.p: Images such as those projected in the folk songs, folk stories, advertisements and obituaries above are popular, familiar, and easily transmitted and received. By contrast the opaque handwritten texts of the Island women diarists could never reach extensive audiences, not only because they are tucked away in obscure locations like archives, but because of their discursive nature. Illegible handwriting, lack of cohesiveness, references to unknown people, gaps in the text as well as information disguised through vague metaphors, all characterize the personal diaries in their handwritten, unedited form.

p.ref: The journal intime, ledger, or diary, by its form and formlessness and absence of any literary conventions to be adhered to, had a particular appeal to women. Here a woman could write when time permitted for whatever length and exercise her literacy on any topic she deemed worthy of recounting. The woman's diary was a safe zone for playing with writing and recording conventions, even self-imposed conventions like writing poetry in the margins, inserting sketches, occasionally hiding information, or partially revealing something. In her diary she was creating a place of her own.

div.p: Contrary to Edward MacDonald's claim about Island women as "silent partners," through their life writing women diarists emerged as agents within their own spheres, wrote out their rapport with nature in minimalist discourse, recorded engagement with current social movements or gave unique descriptions of social intercourse in their immediate surroundings. Women's own portrayals of their roles as mother, wife and homemaker in the context of their life writing defy a strict demarcation of the private sphere of the home and the public sphere. Women's life writing gave depth as well as new perspectives on self-images and their social milieu.

label.title: Inscribing a new world identity: Emma Chadwick Stretch

div.p: Emma Chadwick Stretch migrated to PEI in the late 1850s from England with her husband and children and set up house on a farm in Long River. Emma Chadwick Stretch's 1859-60 diary/account book illustrates the complexity of domesticity when she records her numerous daily transactions as an entrepreneur woven into a rare social documentary of her personal account as a new world subject. Her diary is an account book of tea transactions carried out with the neighbors which evolves into a story of immigration comparable to that of the more famous immigrant narratives of Susanna Moodie and Catherine Parr Trail. What is remarkable is how Emma's journal intime became her vehicle for finding a new voice in her new found land through the telling of the system of bartering she established. While Emma will likely never be written up in the history of business entrepreneurs, she is undoubtedly an example of how women opened female avenues for establishing economic enterprises like those referred to by Charlotte Perkins Gilman in her 1898 manifesto Women and Economics. But what is more important is how Emma sabotaged the autobiographical genre and increasingly used her ledger as that discursive location for inscribing a new world identity.
An excerpt from Emma Chadwick Stretch's 1859 ledger diary illustrates how she succinctly captures her everyday activities of neighbors' visits and her trade of tea and other goods:

p.quote: Friday December 15, A Oldfield came for ½ lb of tea and also Betsy Shaw. Joe went up to Mr Knights. W Hodson borrowed riding saddle.

div.p: But then on Sundays her diary discourse takes on other features. Emma talks of visitors, time alone, children's and even her own health. On Sunday, September 18, 1859 Emma wrote:

p.quote: Took baby down to the beach for a walk children had a sail in the boat H and A Blue came up to tea and Mr. and Mrs. Hodgson spent the evening with us.

div.p: Tea in this entry was a commodity to be enjoyed in the company of neighbors and not a currency of transactions. As an immigrant, Emma's new motherland discourse is refined in her Island circumstances. Between the lines of her tea transactions and her Sunday sojourns in the pastures surrounding her farm, Emma negotiates her new world subject position. Irene Gammel (1999) has suggested ways of understanding the discursive strategies taken up by women in their life writing. Emma's linguistic downplay of certain issues such as her own health, her shifts away from tea transactions, and her peaceful Sundays, all signal her power as author to maneuver positions in her own diary discourse, what Gammel refers to as confessional modalities.

Theatricality and playing with language and theme obviously drew women to the genre. In the shelter of her 1864 travel diary Mercy Ann Coles (daughter of one of PEI's delegates to the historic Quebec Conference which determined Canada's emergence as a sovereign nation) carries on a performance of flirting with Canada's nation builders much in the same way that the nation builder Fathers of Confederation were attempting to seduce the eastern provinces into a political union. Mercy Ann Coles writes:

p.quote: Wednesday morning: We went to the drawing room last night, quite a crowd when we all got together and the ladies looked very well and were quite a credit to the lower Provinces. Pa, Ma and I went together and half the gentlemen wanted to take me but I preferred to go in with Papa. The Governor General stood in the middle of the room with his private secretary on his right, we did not require cards as the aides announced all the time… Mr Tilley took charge of me and walked about with me the whole evening.

div.p: Mercy Ann's linguistic flamboyance in her travel diary juxtaposed with Emma's flat discourse in her shop ledger illustrate just how women were able in their idiosyncratic ways to disrupt the confessional frames and unsettle the confessional reader by their choices of confessional interventions. Emma's absence of intervention, despite being the invisible scribe of transactions of tea and nurse of sick children as she herself fought for her life, became her trademark confessional interventional strategy while Mercy Ann positioned herself in the limelight of Canada's political elite.

p.ref: Pioneer Emma, socialite/dilettante Mercy Ann, grandmother Amy, teacher Lucy, they like so many diarists "encoded boundaries and warnings signaling their desire to create their own space in which to articulate their personal and sexual lives while defying confessional entrapments."Gammel 1 Through their idiosyncratic textual and thematic resolutions the confessional reader is beckoned to pause and consider, why this detail now. Such is the case with my newlywed grandmother and also novice school teacher Lucy Palmer and their confessional modalities or writing strategies and the gaps they interjected when they encountered new situations.

div.p: While these twenty or so diarists fulfilled their autobiographical pact over and over again, day in day out, constructing a self through their oftentimes complex meaning systems, there is no evidence that Island women, other than those of Protestant faith, engaged in life writing. This raises several questions concerning diary writing and the role of religion, and how representative these diaries of Island women actually are. Foremost is the question, did Catholic women keep diaries or participate in the practice of life writing? Religion has been an important part of the cultural baggage immigrants brought to their new destination. Prince Edward Island is a case in point considering how early settlers established their new communities around churches, schools, and shops. Travel down any Island road and every few miles white wooden spires break the pastoral landscapes to indicate that the settlers were primarily either Protestant or Catholic. Today the decommissioning of many of these churches signals religion is not the definitive aspect of Islanders' everyday life it once was.

Women's diaries from the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries give testimony to the interrelatedness of home and community. The shared values of home, school, and church gushed from diarists' pages. Violet Goldsmith, a teacher in Alberton, PEI, wrote in her diary in 1900:

p.quote: Thursday, July 19 Sunday we went to the Presbyterian church morning and evening and to school in the afternoon. Rev Mr. Cairns preached. Mr. McKay addressed school. Mr. Chas Sterns taught the class I was in. Monday was the day of the Catholic tea. Some people came here from Souris. … We had a very nice time at the tea.

div.p: But this diarist along with all of the women diarists in my research were Protestant and wrote from homes, schools, and churches that subscribed to Protestant doctrine. Catholic women did not leave any testimony from the same period. My discussions with the Sisters of the Congregation of Notre Dame and the Sisters of Saint Martha assured me that those Island women who aspired to be nuns were required to write a letter in order to be considered as an entrant to the convent. Such letters from Island women are housed in the archives of the Notre Dame in Montreal and the Sisters of Saint Martha have similar archives on PEI, but permission to view these documents has not been granted. Marta Danylewycz acknowledges that "there was some reluctance on the part of the religious communities to allow historians into the convent. It was and still is the convent's right to deny researchers access to their archival holdings and to discourage their members from talking about themselves and their community to the public."Danylewycz 14 Until these restrictions can be circumvented, no evidence of other life writing has emerged from the pens of Catholic women on Prince Edward Island. The importance of retrieving letters, diaries or other autobiographical documents from Catholic women of this same era would further expand the collection of Island women voices and broaden our understanding of their subjective realities. The cultural memory handed down by Catholic women from this period could be another important source for reformulating our history. As Jan Assman observes, "cultural memory is … handed down, learned, taught, researched, interpreted, and practiced because it is needed, because it belongs to us and for that reason has to be sustained and perpetuated by us."Assman 24

p.ref: For someone like myself, having been born and brought up Catholic on Prince Edward Island, where I also attended convents and was taught by and even lived with nuns and spent my first year of university at St Dunstan's, a Catholic university, before it became non-denominational, there is a sadness in relating the absence of life writing from Catholic women about the experience and history of these institutions, all of which have now been laid to rest. It seems ironic that Catholic women do have a history of social engagement which can only be accessed on a factual level. Between 1881 and 1920 approximately 150 Catholic PEI women joined the religious order of the Congregation of the Notre Dame (CND). In 1857, four sisters arrived on the Island from the Motherhouse in Montreal to extend their tradition of education and social service among Island Catholic. In 1916 sisters from the Congregation of Saint Martha (CND) took up positions in hospitals and numerous other sites, setting in motion a kind of 'feminist spirituality'. The (CND) saw 300 Island women join their order from 1916 to 1982.

div.p: Statistics have indicated a long and almost constant equal distribution of Islanders along religious lines. At the time Emma Chadwick Stretch migrated to Prince Edward Island the distribution of the population according to religion lists 44,416 Protestants (Church of England, Presbyterians, Kirk of Scotland, Methodists, Baptists, Bible Christians and Universalists) and 35,852 Catholic.Journal of the House Assemble, PEI, 1862, Appendix A Diarists like Lucy Palmer Haslam or Violet Goldsmith, both Island school teachers from the 1890s and early 1900s, give some indication of how their religious upbringing and faith inspired their diary writing. Both provide innumerable references to their reading and familiarity with the Bible by quoting biblical texts, listing hymns and accounting the social activities affiliated with their respective churches. On April 6th, 1890 Lucy Palmer wrote:

All drove up to Church. Roads pretty bad. Mr. Millan preached a good sermon for it being Easter Sunday from Luke xxiv.34. … Drove up to Prayer Meeting in evening, Minister read the 27th Chap of Acts. … Charlie Black was there & took Edith home from Church.
Violet Goldsmith, the daughter of a church minister, cultivates and asserts her moral superiority in her 1900 journal:

p.quote: Mr. & Mrs. Holmes went to Fredericton Wed. & Mr. H. came home drunk. The trainman dumped him on the siding & he was there some time before we knew it. Miss Gills, [?] the girl Mrs. H. left in charge & I went down and brought him home. When we got there we found the house full of company. We got a fire on in the parlour & I went down got the company in there. Mr. H. had a bottle of whiskey with him and I ran down the hill with it, broke it against the fence. He was very cross when they first told [him], but he is glad now. He feels very much ashamed of himself the morning.

div.p: Violet's rather picturesquely writes how she walked the moral higher ground by taking control of the situation, confiscating the liquor, and accommodating the visitors.Violet illustrates how her diary serves as a repository of her good deeds, as an expression of accountability to her God.

The literacy that Bible reading facilitates appears to go hand in hand with diary keeping. Women diarists such as Lucy Palmer's sister Amelia often filled pages of her diary with psalms and verse. By contrast their Catholic sisters were not encouraged to read the Bible but instead to follow the reading and interpretation of scripture by their clergy. There is little evidence that Island women rigorously examined themselves and the lives they were leading or how they had fallen away from God, as Catherine A. Brekus indicates that the Puritans did in their devotional diaries. Nor were Lucy and her kind writing for redemption and salvation, but instead most of the women diarists were being faithful to their autobiographical pact to inscribe the self with all its flaws and imperfections which emerged in their everydayness.

For Lucy, Emma and many others, writing a diary was a kind of liberation and their textuality is more serendipitous in its religious referencing and self-examination. On 4 March 1890 Lucy Palmer, spending her third year as a teacher in Malpeque, writes:
Went down to the sewing circle at John Montgomery's had a splendid time a great many there & a beautiful moon light night.

The gaps, metaphors, and vagueness in the Island women's diaries suggested that they were not weaning themselves from their carnal desires as their Puritan sisters did in their diaries but were withholding or masking information about those pleasures they engaged in. Novice teacher Lucy Palmer's repetitive moonlit nights excerpts took on the semblance of a siren yearning for romance as she cautiously admits through references to the moon, the wind, and the sleigh ride her innermost desires. On 28 January 1888 Lucy wrote:

p.quote: It is the loveliest moon light night that I was ever out not a breath of wind. How I would love a sleigh drive.

div.p: This confession to the self, about the self and for the self, appears to have been supported by the urge of these literate Protestant women to preserve their special abilities to read and write and celebrate their affluence of having a pen, pencil, paper or even a diary to put it all in.

The Island diarists discussed here undoubtedly took part in the innermost expression of self through their journal intime, an articulation facilitated by the literary models of the Bible and the conduct manuals of their homes like Vivilore: The Pathway to Mental and Physical Perfection. The Twentieth Century Book for Every Woman. By contrast their Catholic sisters were forced to confess to their priest who would then mediate on their behalf to their God and participate in what Liz Stanley refers to as "an external system of surveillance" associated with organization, power, and audit.Stanley 45 This could partially account for the absence of Catholic women's life writing among nineteenth-century PEI women. For a Catholic woman to confess in her diary would be contrary to her religion and frowned upon. Therefore the existence of, or the survival and preservation of, any documents such as diaries or journals could be evidence that a Catholic woman had sinned by the act of self-examination. Under the watchful eye of church and community Catholic women indulging in self (-ish) scrutiny would not be performing their anticipated role with humility and obedience. What good Catholic family would acknowledge a daughter, sister or mother had been keeping a diary and preserve the document with pride and seek to have it immortalized, making the artifact publicly available in the archives? It appears that Catholic women did not participate in the tradition of diary writing as they had neither the impetus to confess in this way nor the literary impulse which reading and transcribing the Bible instilled in their Protestant sisters. Island women's diaries presented here are part of the extensive body of texts through which one can interrogate women's exclusionary practices in historical discourse and literary formations. But for Catholic women it appears to have been a self-exclusionary practice from the recording process.

For Island women the late 1800s and the early 1900s was a period of "attempting to articulate a subjectivity that has remained unscribed."Prentice et al. 164 It is a fact that few if any Island women are written into the chronicles of Canada's 1867 Confederation despite the fact that PEI is designated the birthplace of Canada and labeled the cradle of Confederation, alluding to the important prescribed feminine preoccupations of maternity. Women like Margaret Gray Lord did witness Confederation but instead of recording the notorious socio-political events of her time in her diary she focuses on her more immediate spheres of influence and her philanthropy through the church, the women's movement, and temperance campaigns, giving us a more nuanced account of her Charlottetown. On 4 January 1897 she wrote:

p.quote: I went into the WCTU (Women’s Christian Temperance Union) to the prayer meeting praying for the success of the prohibition bill.

div.p: Protestant women like Margaret Gray Lord were more individualistic in their response to social issues and recorded engagement with prohibition, the war effort, missionaries, and enfranchisement.

Until more life writing emerges from Island women, more artifacts are found and examined, their visions will remain buried beneath the facts of organizations and institutions. What now appears without these subjective accounts is a history missing the woman's voice. But the Island diarists so far recovered have much to say in their idiosyncratic voices.
